title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: April meeting: Share your favourite thing about R or RStudio  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
There is a sheer endless amount of things to know about R and RStudio – and only this many things you will ever get to know. This holds especially true once you've found a workaround for doing something particular because you're little likely to search for more efficient ways of handling that matter. In our experience, the best way to learn the little things that make an impact is through other useRs.

For our April meetup, we would like to draw from the experiences of other useRs' and ask each of the participants to show their favorite thing about R or RStudio. Whether it's an underused feature, a package, a function or a shortcut you discovered - let us know! If it is a brand new feature of the latest version of R or RStudio – we're happy to hear about it!

There is no need to prepare a fancy presentation on something highly sophisticated. Just take a minute and think about the things that you really like and want others to know about. As always, R users of all levels of expertise are welcome. There is always something new to learn for everyone.

title: R-Ladies Vancouver: How Hockey Taught Me R  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Hello R-Ladies!

Join us on March 25th for a talk on learning R from a sports analytics perspective.

Event Description: Canada's favorite sport isn't just fun to play and fun to watch, it's also a fun tool for learning and using R. I originally taught myself R in order to better analyze hockey, and in this workshop we'll discuss how R sparked my career path as a data analyst as well as work through beginner and intermediate data manipulation techniques from the tidyverse by calculating some box score hockey stats.

About the Speaker: Meghan Hall is a higher ed data professional by day, a hockey analyst by night, and an enthusiastic R user and educator at all hours of the day. She regularly writes and presents on various aspects of hockey analysis and frequently delivers talks and workshops on R. Learn more about Meghan here: https://meghan.rbind.io/.

Workshop details:
Day and time: March 25th, 2021 at 5:30pm
Webinar link: RSVP to view link
Note : Meeting password is embedded in the link after ?pwd
If you have trouble getting into the meeting, please message Jasmin

***
General workshop information:

-Please expect a hands-on session in a friendly and laid-back atmosphere where we all encouraged to learn together.
- All levels!

**********************IMPORTANT************************

1. Have your computer and a steady internet connection ready

2. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

3. Who is this allowed to attend the workshop?
Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming language in data science, which is R.

To fulfill this mission we do ask participants to respect a focus on the encouragement and support for women and non-binary people during our events.

See you there!

Lisa, Jasmine, Lucia, Zubia, and Yuka

title: R-Ladies Santiago: Introducción a Tidymodels (parte 1)  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
Si tienes un manejo básico de R y tidyverse, y quieres comenzar a generar modelos predictivos de regresión o clasificación, este taller es para ti. Veremos las funciones principales del paquete tidymodels y desarrollaremos un modelo lineal de regresión. Esta primera sesión estará a cargo de Sara Acevedo (https://twitter.com/saryace), estudiante de Doctorado en Ciencias de la Ingeniería.

- REQUERIMIENTOS

Antes del taller es necesario que instales los paquetes {tidyverse} y {tidymodels}, junto con sus dependencias:

> install.packages(c("tidyverse", "tidymodels"), dependencies = TRUE)

Asimismo, es necesario tener los paquetes {remotes} y {ggsignif}, junto con sus dependencias:

> install.packages(c("remotes", "ggsignif"), dependencies = TRUE)

Además, debes instalar desde GitHub los paquete {datos} y {corrr} (ojo que tienes que tener instalado el paquete {remotes} para que funcionen las siguientes líneas de código):

> remotes::install_github("cienciadedatos/datos")
> remotes::install_github("tidymodels/corrr")

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA

Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
¡Te esperamos!

title: R-Ladies Philly: 2021 Datathon Kickoff: Exploring Judicial Patterns  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join us for a 6-week datathon focused on exploring judicial patterns in Philadelphia courts! We have partnered with the Judge Accountability Table (JAT; https://judgeaccountabilitytable.org/about/) to help them explore, stratify, and visualize a complex dataset related to public court dockets for defendants in Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania. We will be working on a deidentified subset of these data in order to:

- better understand the judicial system through data
- hone our data science and R skills (there will be ways to contribute for people of all levels of experience with R)
- get our hands dirty and our heads spinning with rich and messy real-world data (spoiler alert: we will not be analyzing sepal.length and petal.width)
- work together, network, and make (new) friends in the data world!
- have fun nerding out together over data :)

Rough Agenda:

- Intro to RLadies Philly datathons
- Partner introduction
- Logistics
- Teams setup and work kickoff

Stay tuned for more updates!

title: R-Ladies Philly: 2021 Datathon Conclusion: Exploring Judicial Patterns  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
The 2021 RLadies Philly hackathon is focused on exploring judicial patterns in Philadelphia courts. Our partner, the Judge Accountability Table (JAT), has provided a subset of deidentified data related to public court dockets for defendants in Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania, to enable participants to hone thier data science skills by:

- Exploring and describing this rich, messy data more completely
- Stratifying data (e.g., comparing simple, low-severity charges with one another and complex, violent crime allegations with one another)
- Answering specific questions, or discovering what additional work or information would be required to be able to answer these questions
- Analyzing sparsity / missingness and discovering what the public interest is in ensuring freedom of information
- Understanding predictive factors in carceral outcomes (e.g. does age / sex / race correlate with bail amount?)

At this meetup, groups will present their results and discuss their experiences.

title: R-Ladies Xalapa: ¿Cómo abrir un capítulo de R-Ladies?, Mexico, Latin America
R-Ladies Brisbane: Using R to analyse step count data: common pitfalls and how to get over them  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
*What are we going to learn:
Interested in analysing health data (like step count)? Not sure how to go about it using R? This talk will cover some common issues researchers and data scientists might encounter when dealing with longitudinal step count data and how R can be used to help with the analysis.

*Who is going to present:
Ly is a Digital Health Scientist and Consultant. Ly is passionate about helping people lead a healthy and happy life. Her current PhD research at Macquarie University leverages how to use AI & mobile technologies to promote healthy behaviour (like physical activity). Ly is a big fan of R and Github, and her favourite packages are ggplot2 and dplyr. Ly loves to share her love of R and learn about it with other people. While Ly is not busy with her R codes, she likes to hang out with her plant babies (all 56 of them) or doing some embroidery.

* When are we meeting?
The talk will start at 5:00 pm for approximately 1.5 hours.

************The presentation will start at 5:00 pm********************
* Where are we meeting?
We will meet virtually using Zoom, the link will be visible to people who RSVP.

* What else is needed?
This will be an interactive ~90 min presentation. If you would like to follow along in RStudio please make sure you have installed the following before the session:

R - https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/base/
RStudio - https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/
Required packages: " dplyr ", ggplot2" and " RMarkdown "

We look forward to seeing you there!

R-Ladies Brisbane

title: R-Ladies Goiânia: Dplyr & Tidyr: A dupla implacável  [Virtual] , Brazil, Latin America
description:
Heey, tudo bem?

Estamos muito felizes com a sua participação.

Aproveite o curso. Aproveite essa oportunidade! Este evento foi pensado com muito carinho para você.

O que você vai aprender?

Você vai aprender a utilizar as diversas funções de manipulação de dados do pacote DPLYR e a criar dados organizados com o pacote TIDYR. Essa dupla de pacotes é SENSACIONAL!

Quais pacotes vão ser utilizados ?

library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)

Sobre o Projeto Enigma

O projeto Enigma busca tornar visível o papel feminino na área da computação, resgatando as contribuições significativas de algumas mulheres de uma forma diferenciada, que provoque o pensamento do fruidor. Não pretende-se reproduzir as visibilidades que estas personagens já têm, mas fazer uma provocação, desacomodando o pensamento para que as invisibilidades, que ainda persistem, se tornem visíveis. As doações serão voltadas a reforma de artigos doados ao projeto como computadores, teclados e entre outros objetos do universo computacional.

Para saber mais sobre este projeto lindo acesse https://www.ufrgs.br/enigma/

E aí? Topa?

Link de inscrição: https://www.sympla.com.br/dplyr--tidyr-a-dulpa-implacavel__1153806

Dúvidas frequentes:

CERTIFICADOS! - O certificado de 4h do evento será enviado para o seu e-mail. Caso você não receba ao final do evento, escreva para [masked].

MATERIAIS! - Os materiais utilizados no nosso curso (apresentação, scripts) serão disponibilizados através do nosso GitHub .

Dicas importantes para melhor aproveitamento do evento

(1°) Procure conectar o seu computador no cabo de rede, evitando instabilidades na transmissão;
(2°) Pré-configure a sua câmera e microfone antes de entrar no evento pois será útil para as interações com a professora em caso de dúvidas!
(3°) Prepare seu ambiente, aquela caneca de café, garrafa de água e os fones de ouvido, melhores companheiros para se concentrar e mergulhar de cabeça nessa experiência!
(4°) Não guarde esse conhecimento apenas para você, compartilhe com seus amigos e redes sociais marcando a gente no instagram @rladiesgyn.

Você faz parte desse compromisso

Lembre-se que o Código de Conduta também se estende à versão online de nossos eventos e não será tolerada qualquer forma de assédios ou intimidações de qualquer participante, seja audiência, palestrantes, colaboradores, ou quaisquer membros da comunidade.

A gente brilha TOGETHER!

title: R-Ladies Bucharest: R-Ladies Bucharest #16: Julia Silge - Three reasons to choose Tidymodels  [Virtual] , Romania, Europe
description:
Join us for a new session on the 23rd of March, 7PM EET ! We continue our meetups with #goodRvibes and a speaker you'll definitely enjoy!

Three reasons to use tidymodels with Julia Silge

Modeling and machine learning in R involve a bewildering array of heterogeneous packages, and establishing good statistical practice is challenging in any language. The tidymodels (tidymodels.org) collection of packages offers a consistent, flexible framework for your modeling and machine learning work to address these problems. In this talk, we’ll focus on three specific reasons to consider using tidymodels. We will start with model characteristics themselves, move to the wise management of your data budget, and finish with feature engineering.

Julia Silge is a data scientist and software engineer at RStudio PBC where she works on open source modeling tools. She is an author, an international keynote speaker, and a real-world practitioner focusing on data analysis and machine learning practice. Julia loves text analysis, making beautiful charts, and communicating about technical topics with diverse audiences.

Registration is free, but mandatory via meetup. We shall meet on zoom, and the link will be updated on the day of the event ( PIN for entrance should be sent by email ~2hours before meeting start).

description: Jenna K. spent the summer of 2020 working on the R package lmeresampler (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/lmeresampler/index.html). title: R-Ladies Irvine: Undergraduate Research with Graduate Topics & Experimental Design with Tidyverse  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, March 16, 6:30-8:00 pm (Pacific)
6:30 - Welcome and Networking
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - Undergraduate Research with Graduate Level Topics
7:25 - Q&A
7:30 - Modernizing Design of Experiment Output with Tidyverse
7:55 - Q&A
8:00 - Meeting Adjourned

# Undergraduate Research with Graduate Level Topics
Speaker: Jessica Jaynes, PhD
Assistant Professor of Statistics, Department of Mathematics, CSU Fullerton

Bio: Dr. Jessica Jaynes is an Assistant Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics at California State University, Fullerton. She received her Ph.D. in Statistics from the University of California, Los Angeles. Her area of expertise includes design of experiments, statistical methods and applications, survey methods, and discrete choice experiments. Her recent projects include the development of a new class of experimental designs that provide higher efficiency, more in-depth analyses, and require a shorter time to run. This research has led to multiple interdisciplinary funded projects.

Abstract: As science and technology progress, this often calls for innovation in methodological and theoretical development of statistical experimental design, an essential aspect for research in any discipline. This research concentrates on the close connection between statistics and medicine, and the development of novel experiments to maximize efficiency, while minimizing time and costs. The focus of this talk will be on an application of an undergraduate research project using a novel experimental design known as an Orthogonal Array Composite Design (OACD) with applications to KB oral cancer. In particular, this talk will highlight the methods and applications that undergraduate students contributed to. Furthermore, various takeaways will be presented in terms of tips, challenges, and benefits in working with undergraduate students. sources.

# Modernizing Design of Experiment Output with Tidyverse
Speaker: Jose Toledo
Graduate Student, Statistics Dept, CSU Fullerton

Bio: Jose is currently in his last semester in the Master’s in statistics program at California State University, Fullerton (CSUF), where he is also a teaching associate. Additionally, he is a part-time data analyst at Southern California Coast Water Project. His research interest is in the field of Design of Experiments, where he has worked on projects such as drug combination treatments for KB oral cancer and recently in tuberculosis. During his summer breaks he enjoys mentoring undergraduate students in local community colleges and providing them research opportunities early in their education.

Abstract: Most Design of Experiment (DoE) experts will agree that using FrF2 is the most comprehensive R package for generating two-level factorial designs as well as Plackett-Burman type screening designs. Similarly, for sequential optimization with first order and second order response surface models, that offer optimization approaches like steepest ascent and visualization of the response function for linear model objects, the package rsm is highly recommended. However, their graphical outputs are limited and can benefit from the current “trends” in R such as implementing graphics using ggplot2. This talk will focus on the development of an R package, ggDoE, which focuses on the visualization of DoE using ggplot2. Examples will be taken from a TB drug combination experiment and demonstrate the output of commonly used methods in DoE. These methods include but are not limited to: factorial effect plots, half-normal plots, Lenth’s method, fitting second-order models and their corresponding contour plots.

# Meeting Materials
All meeting materials will be sent to registered attendees after the event.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {Part 3: Wrangling} From Zero to (s)Hero: Multi-part intro to R  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Just getting involved with R or want to level up your skills? Have you used base-R but are still trying to wrap your head around the tidyverse "pipe" (%>%)? Have a messy dataset and don't know where to start? Seen beautiful visualizations on Twitter and want to make your own?

If you’ve answered ‘yes’ to at least one of these questions, fear no more! In this monthly workshop series, we will walk you through the fundamental uses of tidyverse and ggplot at your own pace with the help of hands-on exercises. Tidyverse and ggplot are a classic combination of R packages that allow you to "wrangle" your unwieldy data into whatever shape you need and creative beautiful and informative visualizations.

Over the course of this series, you will learn the most useful features of R Studio and R Markdown, how to read in and explore data, and transform it into a shape that's easy to work with. You will be able to create new columns and summary tables, subset interesting rows or columns, and combine and reshape dataframes. We will also dive into ggplot, one of the best tools for creating great-looking bar charts, scatterplots, and more!

This is (currently) a five-part series, aimed at total beginners and/or people with some experience in base-R or tidyverse who are looking to freshen up or expand their skills. Feel free to join at any point, we will briefly review the previous topic at the beginning of each session.

January 20th {Part 1}: The R & R-Studio ABCs (packages, files, data types & basic data exploration)
February 17th {Part 2}: Tidy data & introduction to data wrangling (tibbles, renaming, reordering, subsetting)
March 17th {Part 3}: Data wrangling with dplyr (new columns, if-else statements, summary tables, joining dataframes)
April 21st {Part 4}: Introduction to visualizations with ggplot (line graphs, bar charts, scatterplots, histograms, and more!)
May 19th {Part 5}: Advanced topics in wrangling and ggplot (pivoting, ggplot style options, etc.)

Please install R and R-Studio before joining: https://rstudio-education.github.io/hopr/starting.html

Image by the amazing @allison_horst: https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {R-Ladies Toolbox Series} Part 4: Version Control  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
R-Ladies Toolbox Series - Essentials for women and minority genders in academia, science and data analysis presents:

--> Version Control by Christin Zasada (R-Ladies Global Team, R-Ladies Berlin) <--

Calling all students, academics, and women in science! R-Ladies Freiburg presents a five-part guest series aimed at women and gender minorities in academia, science and data analysis, from first semester students to tenured researchers. Leading R-Ladies from around the world will lead us through the most fundamental steps to studying and working in academia, from analyzing results, to presenting them clearly, ensuring their reproducibility, and keeping track of all your changes. The series will close with a panel discussion from women around the world, who will speak about their experiences with science.

This series is funded by the “Pädagogische Hochschule Freiburg”, the University of Education in Freiburg.

Participants who take part in all five meetups can receive a certificate of participation.

Everyone is welcome to join and we hope for a warm exchange between students and researchers, as well as R-Ladies from the wider community.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {Part 4: Visualization} From Zero to (s)Hero: Multi-part intro to R  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Just getting involved with R or want to level up your skills? Have you used base-R but are still trying to wrap your head around the tidyverse "pipe" (%>%)? Have a messy dataset and don't know where to start? Seen beautiful visualizations on Twitter and want to make your own?

If you’ve answered ‘yes’ to at least one of these questions, fear no more! In this monthly workshop series, we will walk you through the fundamental uses of tidyverse and ggplot at your own pace with the help of hands-on exercises. Tidyverse and ggplot are a classic combination of R packages that allow you to "wrangle" your unwieldy data into whatever shape you need and creative beautiful and informative visualizations.

Over the course of this series, you will learn the most useful features of R Studio and R Markdown, how to read in and explore data, and transform it into a shape that's easy to work with. You will be able to create new columns and summary tables, subset interesting rows or columns, and combine and reshape dataframes. We will also dive into ggplot, one of the best tools for creating great-looking bar charts, scatterplots, and more!

This is (currently) a five-part series, aimed at total beginners and/or people with some experience in base-R or tidyverse who are looking to freshen up or expand their skills. Feel free to join at any point, we will briefly review the previous topic at the beginning of each session.

January 20th {Part 1}: The R & R-Studio ABCs (packages, files, data types & basic data exploration)
February 17th {Part 2}: Tidy data & introduction to data wrangling (tibbles, renaming, reordering, subsetting)
March 17th {Part 3}: Data wrangling with dplyr (new columns, if-else statements, summary tables, joining dataframes)
April 21st {Part 4}: Introduction to visualizations with ggplot (line graphs, bar charts, scatterplots, histograms, and more!)
May 19th {Part 5}: Advanced topics in wrangling and ggplot (pivoting, ggplot style options, etc.)

Please install R and R-Studio before joining: https://rstudio-education.github.io/hopr/starting.html

Image by the amazing @allison_horst: https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations

title: AthensR: "officeverse : creating Word and PowerPoint documents with R" with David Gohel  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
## Abstract

officeverse : a set of packages to ease the production of Word and PowerPoint documents

The officer package has been developed to facilitate the production of Word documents and PowerPoint presentations with R.

The initial project was to offer an alternative solution to SAS ODS for tabular and graphical reports produced in Word for one of my clients. The range of functionalities has expanded and some very interesting extensions have been created. There is the officedown package that increases the layout capabilities of R Markdown when the output is Word, the rvg package to create editable vector graphics, the flextable package to make nice tables.

In this presentation, you will see how to use the package to produce PowerPoint presentations and Word documents. Its role as a foundation for other packages and new documentation will be discussed. It will also be an opportunity for David to present the officedown package for the first time.

## Speaker

David Gohel is the founder of ArData, a French company providing R expertise, R training and consulting in data sciences. He is the author of R packages, most popular are officer, flextable, rvg and ggiraph.

He is a data scientist and software engineer. His professional experiences led him to face many challenges related to the data of organizations, which he has always managed with solutions involving R software.

title: R-Ladies Valparaíso: Introducción a Tidymodels (parte 1)  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
Si tienes un manejo básico de R y tidyverse, y quieres comenzar a generar modelos predictivos de regresión o clasificación, este taller es para ti. Veremos las funciones principales del paquete tidymodels y desarrollaremos un modelo lineal de regresión. Esta primera sesión estará a cargo de Sara Acevedo (https://twitter.com/saryace), estudiante de Doctorado en Ciencias de la Ingeniería.

- REQUERIMIENTOS

Antes del taller es necesario que instales los paquetes {tidyverse} y {tidymodels}, junto con sus dependencias:

> install.packages(c("tidyverse", "tidymodels"), dependencies = TRUE)

Asimismo, es necesario tener los paquetes {remotes} y {ggsignif}, junto con sus dependencias:

> install.packages(c("remotes", "ggsignif"), dependencies = TRUE)

Además, debes instalar desde GitHub los paquete {datos} y {corrr} (ojo que tienes que tener instalado el paquete {remotes} para que funcionen las siguientes líneas de código):

> remotes::install_github("cienciadedatos/datos")
> remotes::install_github("tidymodels/corrr")

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA

Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish

¡Te esperamos!

title: R-Ladies East Lansing: R-package development  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
“Develop an R package”, they said… What does this even mean?

In this session with a live demo, we shall demystify the creation of an R package. R packages are mostly well-organized folders, and there are automatic tools to help. Let’s dive into the wonders of usethis! We shall also see why to create a package (or not). We shall furthermore explain how to improve your R package and your own package development skills. And how to solve the specific new challenges you will encounter! Last but not least we will discuss how to find your happy place in the world of R package development.

Do you want to be more of a devoted maintainer of one single package? Or perhaps a valued contributor to dozens of packages?

==================
About the Speaker
==================
Maelle Salmon is a R(esearch) Software Engineer & Blogger based in Nancy, France. She is also the associate editor for rOpenSci’s Software Peer Review (peer-review system of R packages), and the main manager of R-Ladies Global Twitter account (@RLadiesGlobal).

title: R-Ladies Madrid: Taller: analiza datos espaciales con raster  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
¡Quinto taller online de R-Ladies Madrid!

¡En marzo nos vamos de viaje espacial con Stephanie Orellana! Hemos aprendido los básicos de R, cómo manejar y visualizar datos, y cómo reportar con RMarkdown. Pero vamos en este taller vamos a introducirnos en una especialización: manejar datos de tipo espacial. ¿Qué tienen de particular y cómo analizarlos?

Los requisitos de este taller son tener instaladas las siguientes librerías: {sf}, {raster}, {tidyverse}, {mapview}

title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: [ONLINE]- Introduction to Tidyverse  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
Hi, everybody!
We hope that you and your family are doing well. We are super excited to have Nutsa Nanuashvili, a data enthusiast that recently graduated in Cognitive Sciences to introduce you to the tidyverse universe!

DESCRIPTION
-------------------
The goal of this workshop is to get familiar with some useful and easy to use data transformation techniques in R. For this, we are going to go through some handy functions and commands from the famous tidyverse ecosystem. Hopefully with these tricks and tips you’re going to get more confident around transforming & organizing data.
During the meeting we will discuss some concepts and provide code examples, after which we’ll go through exercises to try out the newly learned concepts by ourselves. Some of the topics we’ll cover are, tidy data concept, reshaping datasets, what is and how to use the pipe %>% operator, and manipulating data columns and rows.
For all these we're going to use the dataset about penguins from palmerpenguins package.

PROGRAMME
----------------------
18.30- 18.45 Virtual Welcome
18.45- 20.30 Workshop and Q&A

ABOUT NUTSA
-------------------
I recently graduated with a master’s degree in Cognitive Neuroscience from the University of Amsterdam, Institute of Interdisciplinary Studies. I love programming and working on data. I especially love coding in R and I used it a lot while doing my master's projects. While looking for new adventures, I enjoy working on data and learning new concepts as part of my side-projects.

PREREQUISITES
-----------------------
A basic knowledge of R is recommended. Please install the tidyverse package.

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: EdinbR: The Edinburgh R Usergroup: March 2021: diabetes on social media and styling interactive outputs  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
description:
Hi everyone!

The third session of 2021 will be on March 17th, join us from 5.30pm online! As usual, the meeting will be open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are very welcome.

Our online meetings are kindly being enabled by Red Hat (https://www.redhat.com/). In order to join us you need to register with MeetUp (https://www.meetup.com/EdinbR/).

Our speakers are Mirjam Eiswirth and Elliot Meador.

* **Mirjam Eiswirth** (https://twitter.com/@MirjamIce) is a postdoctoral researcher at the sociolinguistics lab at the University of Duisburg-Essen. Before moving to Germany, she finished her PhD in Linguistics and English Language at the University of Edinburgh. She mostly works on variation and change in language in interaction.

* **Elliot Meador** (https://www.thedeltanomics.com) is a computational social scientist and data scientist working as a research fellow within the Rural Policy Centre at SRUC in Edinburgh, UK. His work focuses on mapping rural resilience in Scotland and understanding how policy impacts community resilience. Elliot’s research also looks at how information on sustainable agriculture practices is shared between farmers and how this influences behaviour change related to sustainable development.

---

## Do people with Type 1 Diabetes talk and tweet about the same things?

### Mirjam Eiswirth
In this presentation I explore ways of comparing a set of transcribed conversational data with a set of data from Twitter. I specifically look at 24 hours of recordings of talk about Type 1 Diabetes relative to Tweets within the context of the diabetes online community. This comparison allows us to assess how representative the concerns raised in the conversations are of the world-wide discourses around Type 1 Diabetes on English-language Twitter, and in how far they are specific to the participants or to the location these participants are from.

---

## Does it have to look like a 90’s website? Introduction to CSS and HTML for styling interactive outputs in R

### Elliot Meador

In this talk we will review some easy wins when it comes to styling interactive outputs in R, including Shiny web applications and flexdashboards. Specifically, we’ll discuss Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) and how they can be used to add some pizazz to the base Shiny and flexdashboards. We will then discuss layouts and workflows that are best suited for styling your interactive R outputs.

---

See you there!

/federico

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - Data Feminism  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Data Feminism (https://www.bookdepository.com/Data-Feminism-Catherine-DIgnazio/9780262044004).

A new way of thinking about data science and data ethics that is informed by the ideas of intersectional feminism.

Today, data science is a form of power. It has been used to expose injustice, improve health outcomes, and topple governments. But it has also been used to discriminate, police, and surveil. This potential for good, on the one hand, and harm, on the other, makes it essential to ask: Data science by whom? Data science for whom? Data science with whose interests in mind? The narratives around big data and data science are overwhelmingly white, male, and techno-heroic. In Data Feminism, Catherine D'Ignazio and Lauren Klein present a new way of thinking about data science and data ethics—one that is informed by intersectional feminist thought.

Illustrating data feminism in action, D'Ignazio and Klein show how challenges to the male/female binary can help challenge other hierarchical (and empirically wrong) classification systems. They explain how, for example, an understanding of emotion can expand our ideas about effective data visualization, and how the concept of invisible labor can expose the significant human efforts required by our automated systems. And they show why the data never, ever “speak for themselves.”

Data Feminism offers strategies for data scientists seeking to learn how feminism can help them work toward justice, and for feminists who want to focus their efforts on the growing field of data science. But Data Feminism is about much more than gender. It is about power, about who has it and who doesn't, and about how those differentials of power can be challenged and changed..

PS This book is available free online: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Studying mental health and evaluating policies during the COVID-19 pandemic  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
We are very excited to welcome Dr. Elizabeth Stuart, an internationally renowned expert in statistics, education, and mental health!

Elizabeth A. Stuart, Ph.D. is Bloomberg Professor of American Health in the Department of Mental Health at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, with joint appointments in the Department of Biostatistics and the Department of Health Policy and Management. She received her Ph.D. in statistics in 2004 from Harvard University and is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association (ASA) and the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS). Prior to her time at JHSPH she was a Researcher at Mathematica Policy Research. Dr. Stuart has extensive experience in methods for estimating causal effects and dealing with the complications of missing data in experimental and non-experimental studies, particularly as applied to mental health, public policy, and education. Her primary research interests include designs for estimating causal effects in non-experimental settings (such as propensity scores), and methods to assess and enhance the generalizability of randomized trials to target populations, and she teaches courses and short courses on these topics. She has received research funding for her work from the National Science Foundation, the Institute of Education Sciences, the WT Grant Foundation, and the National Institutes of Health and has served on advisory panels for the National Academy of Sciences, the US Department of Education, and the Patient Centered Outcomes Research Institute.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: This month, I learned ...  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
No matter how much you learn, there always seems to be something new in the world of R. How do you keep abreast of the changes, and keep your knowledge up-to-date?

In this talk, I'll share some things I learned this month, and how I went about it. It will cover an eclectic mix of new things from packages in the tidyverse, R and RStudio.

I hope you'll either learn something new, or learn a new strategy for staying up to date.

Charlotte Wickham is Data Scientist, instructor at Oregon State University, and specialist in R training. I'm available for R training and data science consulting.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Exploring Our Universe Through Sight & Sound (or Touch!)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Information of cosmic objects doesn't have to be just a two-dimensional snap shot. We can transform these data to be able to listen, feel, or (virtually) move through the cosmos through virtual reality and even holograms. Such data taken from telescopes in space – often in light invisible to the human eye – can be translated into many different forms to help provide access to some of space’s most interesting and mysterious objects. Dr. Kimberly Arcand, from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory, will take you to the debris from an exploded star through sound, walk you through the core of our Milky Way virtually, discuss feeling vibrations of a stellar nursery, and help you experience our universe anew.

For information about our speaker, Kimberly Arcand, please go to https://www.kimarcand.com/about.

title: Dublin R: Why R? Webinars: "Data Optimization Networks" with Gaurav Pahuja  [Virtual] , Ireland, Europe
description:
- channel: youtube.com/c/WhyRFoundationVideos
- format: one 45 minutes long stream + 10 minutes for Q&A
- MC: Kevin O'Brien & Guests
- comments: ask questions on YouTube live chat
- join Why R? Slack whyr.pl/slack/
- LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/why-r
- Twitter: https://twitter.com/whyrconf/

Abstract:
The Data Optimisation Network (DON) seeks to improve business decision making using machine intelligence and data science techniques. It predicts customer behaviour through data driven insights to enable business to acquire new customer intelligently. Main Key problem with most of the companies is not just to acquire more customers but it is to acquire the right customers and retain them. Companies consider the cost of customer acquisition as an important measure in evaluating how much value a customer will bring to their businesses. DON will empower teams such as Customer Value Management, Marketing, Sales, Continuous Improvement and more via interactive dashboards available in real time. These dashboards will enable research and the understanding of market trends and behaviours. The demonstration of the app is based on utility sector. However, the data is anonymised for the solution but depicts the real life problem.

Biography: Process oriented Data Scientist with 9 years of experience. I am a conscientious person who works hard and pays attention to the detail. Experienced in interpreting and analysing data to drive growth of the company. I am an effective communicator with excellent interpersonal relationship and management skills. My greatest strength is strong analytical thinking, which enables me to furnish insights, analyse data, build machine learning and deep learning models to leverage business to guide their decisions. I am also experienced in coordinating with stakeholders. I create content on YouTube to help others in the data science field; I am qualified gym instructor and personal trainer.

title: Dublin R: #GlobalR: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science March Meetup  [Virtual] , Ireland, Europe
description:
This is an external event. To RSVP - go to https://www.meetup.com/Newcastle-Upon-Tyne-Data-Science-Meetup/events/275548174/

Alastair Rushworth (Tesco Bank)

Title: Exploring EDA with R

Abstract: Exploratory data analysis (aka EDA) is one of the most important tools in the data scientist’s toolkit, while also being one of the hardest to codify and teach. EDA is often understood as an exercise undertaken at the beginning of a data science project, to expose insights and patterns that support, and eventually give way to more formal modelling or statistical analysis. But is this sufficient, or is there more to EDA than that? In this talk I will attempt to dig deeper into what EDA is for and how it can support an iterative process of learning and discovery, while also demonstrating some of the great R packages and tools that I have found useful along the way.

Matthew Higgs

Title: What can data scientists learn from data-driven responses to Covid-19?

Abstract: Data-driven responses to Covid-19 have been developed at speed across the public sector, academia, and commercial sector - leading to a range of successes, failures, and opportunities for lessons to be learned. At the ‘Observatory for Monitoring Data-Driven Approaches to Covid-19’ (omddac.org.uk) we are analysing key data-driven responses to Covid-19 and collating lessons learned by way of stakeholder interviews, case study analysis, and representative public surveys. In this talk, I will highlight some key findings from our stakeholder interviews and reflect on the role of data science during the Covid-19 pandemic. I will discuss successful applications of data science, ethical issues to be aware of, and what stakeholders *really* think about working with data scientists.

Bio: Matthew Higgs MMath, PhD is a Lecturer in the Department of Computing and Information Sciences at Northumbria University and a Co-Investigator on the UKRI-funded project ‘Observatory for Monitoring Data-Driven Approaches to Covid-19’ (omddac.org.uk). Since completing his PhD in Computational Statistics and Machine Learning at University College London in 2011, Matthew has worked in technical and non-technical roles in academia, the commercial sector, and the public sector - with a focus on managing diverse stakeholders and developing data-driven products and solutions.

title: Dublin R: Why R? Webinars:  officeverse : creating Word and PowerPoint documents with R  [Virtual] , Ireland, Europe
description:

- format: one 45 minutes long stream + 10 minutes for Q&A
- MC: Lais Carvalho & Guests
- comments: ask questions on YouTube live chat
- join Why R? Slack whyr.pl/slack/
- LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/why-r
- Twitter: https://twitter.com/whyrconf/

Description:
officeverse : a set of packages to ease the production of Word and PowerPoint documents

## Abstract

officeverse : a set of packages to ease the production of Word and PowerPoint documents

The officer package has been developed to facilitate the production of Word documents and PowerPoint presentations with R.

The initial project was to offer an alternative solution to SAS ODS for tabular and graphical reports produced in Word for one of my clients. The range of functionalities has expanded and some very interesting extensions have been created. There is the officedown package that increases the layout capabilities of R Markdown when the output is Word, the rvg package to create editable vector graphics, the flextable package to make nice tables.

In this presentation, you will see how to use the package to produce PowerPoint presentations and Word documents. Its role as a foundation for other packages and new documentation will be discussed. It will also be an opportunity for David to present the officedown package for the first time.

## Speaker

David Gohel is the founder of ArData, a French company providing R expertise, R training and consulting in data sciences. He is the author of R packages, most popular are officer, flextable, rvg and ggiraph.

He is a data scientist and software engineer. His professional experiences led him to face many challenges related to the data of organizations, which he has always managed with solutions involving R software.

description:
- channel: youtube.com/c/WhyRFoundationVideos

- MC: Kevin O'Brien
- comments: ask questions on YouTube live chat
- join Why R? Slack whyr.pl/slack/
- LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/why-r
- Twitter: https://twitter.com/whyrconf/

"Analysing Political Speeches in R: Some Approaches"

Abstract: Legislative debate transcripts can provide unique insights into politics and policy. They can be used to identify popular topics among different legislators, reveal party factions that do not show up in voting behaviour, and longitudinal changes in the language used to discuss certain topics, amongst other things. In this webinar I'll discuss some approaches and potential pitfalls to analysing legislative debate, using the British House of Commons as an example.

Biography: Evan Odell is a junior data consultant at Pandata and R programmer, based in Berlin. Evan has written numerous R packages, primarily for accessing and processing data, and created a dataset of UK House of Commons speeches available as a single RDS or CSV file. He has previously worked for Disability Rights UK, Queen's University and as a freelancer for London Business School.

title: R-Ladies RTP: Navigating RStudio & R Basics  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
By the end of this event, participants will be able to describe the main components of RStudio (e.g., console, script editor, etc.). They will also be able to explain basic R syntax (e.g, "(" versus "["), data types (e.g., character versus integer), and programming concepts (e.g., functions versus packages). We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

Agenda:
• 6:30pm - 6:45pm - Introductions
• 6:45pm - 7:00pm - Navigating RStudio
• 7:00pm - 8:00pm - R Basics
• 8:00pm - 8:20pm - Practice
• 8:20m - 8:30pm - Wrap up

Who is this for?
This meetup is for beginners who have **no experience** programming in R (or another coding language). We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

**Before you join**, please install the most recent version of R **as well as** RStudio on your computer before attending this meetup event. Here are links to free downloads for R (https://cran.r-project.org/) and RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download). Downloading and installing both of these programs before this meetup will help us keep to our schedule and make sure you learn the most you can while at the meetup event.

If you have trouble installing the software, please contact Sheila at [masked] at least 48 hours **before the event** so we can find a time to meet and work through software installation issues.

What should I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the capabilities to run R **and** RStudio. See information above about how to install R **and** RStudio.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

title: R-Ladies RTP: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

The dataset we will explore will be posted before we meet.

Agenda:
7:00 - 7:15 pm Meet & Greet
7:15 - 8:30 pm #tidytuesday
8:30 - 9:00 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a cozy beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday @ 三創育成 | An introduction to Causal Inference and ..., Taiwan, Asia
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
本次聚會地點於三創育成基金會（11F）場地

講題：An introduction to Causal Inference and Identification Strategies in observational studies

講題介紹：在大數據的資料分析中，我們常常需要客觀的評估某個intervention 對outcome 是否有因果關係，以及因果效應有多顯著。由於在流行病學、計量經濟學以及生物統計中，面對的資料大都是觀察性資料，必須透過 Causal Inference 的方法，降低 Selection Bias，才能得到正確的因果效應的估計。

本次演講將透過 Rubin 的 Potential outcome framework 以及 Judea Pearl 的 DAG 方法，解釋資料裡面的 Selection bias 以及 Confounding factors，以及如何去掉這些干擾。也會介紹一些常用的識別策略，像是 Matching、回歸以及工具變數法來推估因果效應。

講者介紹：Allen Kao

華碩 AICS Senior Director，在團隊中負責電子病歷大數據產品研發以及 Computer Vision 技術研發，有多年的軟體產品開發經驗。

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday @ 三創育成 | Big Data Analytics and Machine Learning Systems ..., Taiwan, Asia
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
本次聚會地點於三創育成基金會（11F）場地

講題：Big Data Analytics and Machine Learning Systems: The Apache Way

講題介紹：這個talk分上下兩部分。前面偏技術性，我會以兩個專案Apache Ozone以及Apache Submarine分享Big Data Analytics Systems以及Machine Learning Systems開發最新的現況。Ozone是個專門設計給Big data workload儲存大量資料的object store, Submarine 是個開源的機器學習平台。

後半部偏軟性，作為Apache Hadoop VP，我會分享這幾年在世界open source環境參與的心得，以及這幾年在台灣推動open source開發、建立社群的心得。

講者介紹：Wei-Chiu currently serves as the VP of Apache Hadoop. He joined Cloudera in 2015 as a software engineer, where he leads the development of Cloudera’s distributed storage system: the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS).

He is an active committer and Project Management Committee member in various Apache open source projects, including Apache Hadoop, HBase and Submarine and Ozone.
Wei-Chiu received his Ph.D. in Computer Science from Purdue University for his research in distributed systems and programming models.

title: R-Ladies Dallas: Data Storytelling with Amber Thomas  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For the March 16th edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome Amber Thomas as our guest speaker. Amber will introduce the topic of data storytelling.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Session title: Telling Data Stories at The Pudding
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract: At The Pudding, we create data-driven, visual essays. But how do we go from a basic idea all the way to a finished, interactive experience? In this talk, I'll cover where our ideas come from, how we choose which ones to pursue, and our entire process from idea to completion.

Bio: Amber is a Senior Journalist Engineer at The Pudding, where her work focuses primarily on communicating complex topics and ideas, designing and developing data visualizations for the web, and improving the accessibility of information for a general audience. Before starting at The Pudding in 2017, Amber was a marine biologist and a research scientist.

title: R-Ladies Concepción: Introducción a Tidymodels  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
Si tienes un manejo básico de R y tidyverse, y quieres comenzar a generar modelos predictivos de regresión o clasificación, este taller es para ti. Veremos las funciones principales del paquete tidymodels y desarrollaremos un modelo lineal de regresión. Esta primera sesión estará a cargo de Sara Acevedo (https://twitter.com/saryace), estudiante de Doctorado en Ciencias de la Ingeniería.

- REQUERIMIENTOS
Antes del taller es necesario que instales los paquetes {tidyverse} y {tidymodels}, junto con sus dependencias:
> install.packages(c("tidyverse", "tidymodels")), dependencies = TRUE)
Asimismo, es necesario tener los paquetes {remotes} y {ggsignif}, junto con sus dependencias:
> install.packages(c("remotes", "ggsignif")), dependencies = TRUE)
Además, debes instalar desde GitHub los paquete {datos} y {corrr} (ojo que tienes que tener instalado el paquete {remotes} para que funcionen las siguientes líneas de código):
> remotes::install_github("cienciadedatos/datos")
> remotes::install_github("tidymodels/corrr")

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish

¡Te esperamos!

title: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup: March Meet-up  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup
description:
Alastair Rushworth (Tesco Bank)

Title: Exploring EDA with R

Abstract: Exploratory data analysis (aka EDA) is one of the most important tools in the data scientist’s toolkit, while also being one of the hardest to codify and teach. EDA is often understood as an exercise undertaken at the beginning of a data science project, to expose insights and patterns that support, and eventually give way to more formal modeling or statistical analysis. But is this sufficient, or is there more to EDA than that? In this talk I will attempt to dig deeper into what EDA is for and how it can support an iterative process of learning and discovery, while also demonstrating some of the great R packages and tools that I have found useful along the way.

Matthew Higgs

Title: What can data scientists learn from data-driven responses to Covid-19?

Abstract: Data-driven responses to Covid-19 have been developed at speed across the public sector, academia, and commercial sector - leading to a range of successes, failures, and opportunities for lessons to be learned. At the ‘Observatory for Monitoring Data-Driven Approaches to Covid-19’ (omddac.org.uk) we are analysing key data-driven responses to Covid-19 and collating lessons learned by way of stakeholder interviews, case study analysis, and representative public surveys. In this talk, I will highlight some key findings from our stakeholder interviews and reflect on the role of data science during the Covid-19 pandemic. I will discuss successful applications of data science, ethical issues to be aware of, and what stakeholders *really* think about working with data scientists.

Bio: Matthew Higgs MMath, PhD is a Lecturer in the Department of Computing and Information Sciences at Northumbria University and a Co-Investigator on the UKRI-funded project ‘Observatory for Monitoring Data-Driven Approaches to Covid-19’ (omddac.org.uk). Since completing his PhD in Computational Statistics and Machine Learning at University College London in 2011, Matthew has worked in technical and non-technical roles in academia, the commercial sector, and the public sector - with a focus on managing diverse stakeholders and developing data-driven products and solutions.
